elements.content: Two-dimensional functional metal–organic frameworks and coordination polymers have attracted much attention and have been successfully prepared in solutions and at interfaces through the coordination of ligands to metal ions. However, the preparation of large-area ultrathin ordered films is still a challenge. Here, a modified liquid/liquid interfacial epitaxial growth method has been developed. A planar liquid/liquid interface between a chloroform solution of bipyridine derivatives and pure water was constructed first, and then an aqueous solution of Eu3+ or Cu2+ ions was added dropwise into the water phase. A layered ultrathin film with the size of several hundreds of square micrometers appeared at the liquid/liquid interface after a certain time. The monitoring results showed that the formation of ultrathin films was a result of continuous epitaxial growth of the adsorbed species due to the synergistic effects of hydrophobic effects of the alkyl chains, coordination bonds between the ligands and metal ions, π–π interactions between the ligands, and the restriction of the interface on the vertical growth. This offers a way to fabricate more large-area thin films of amphiphilic molecules.

elements.content: Ultrathin layered two-dimensional (2D) nanostructures have attracted much attention in recent years due to their regular and ordered structures, novel optical, electronic, catalytic and transport properties, and wide applications in various areas. In terms of composition, 2D nanostructures, which appeared mainly as nanosheets, can be divided into inorganic, organic, and hybrid structures, such as metals and metal compounds, graphene and its derivatives, covalent organic frameworks (COFs), metal organic frameworks (MOFs), and coordination polymers. Among them, MOFs and coordination polymers formed by ligands and metal ions through coordination bonds have aroused more and more interest recently. Because of the directionality and weaker interaction characteristics of the coordination bonds, MOFs and coordination polymers with designed regular structures can be obtained easily under ambient conditions. On the other hand, the coordination bond is stronger than other intermolecular interactions; hence, MOFs and coordination polymers are more stable than some supramolecular systems. In general, coordination polymers have cavities and a layered structure, which give them high potential for application in catalytic, transport, and separation areas.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Ultrathin layered two-dimensional (2D) nanostructures have attracted much attention in recent years due to their regular and ordered structures, novel optical, electronic, catalytic and transport properties, and wide applications in various areas. In terms of composition, 2D nanostructures, which appeared mainly as nanosheets, can be divided into inorganic, organic, and hybrid structures, such as metals and metal compounds, graphene and its derivatives, covalent organic frameworks (COFs), metal organic frameworks (MOFs), and coordination polymers. Among them, MOFs and coordination polymers formed by ligands and metal ions through coordination bonds have aroused more and more interest recently. Because of the directionality and weaker interaction characteristics of the coordination bonds, MOFs and coordination polymers with designed regular structures can be obtained easily under ambient conditions. On the other hand, the coordination bond is stronger than other intermolecular interactions; hence, MOFs and coordination polymers are more stable than some supramolecular systems. In general, coordination polymers have cavities and a layered structure, which give them high potential for application in catalytic, transport, and separation areas.

elements.content: Two main strategies have been applied to prepare such 2D nanostructures, namely, exfoliation and synthesis/assembly. The 2D nanostructures can be synthesized or assembled in solutions and at interfaces. The liquid/solid, air/liquid, and liquid/liquid interfaces, and even the gas/solid interface, have been utilized to construct 2D MOFs and polymers. As for the synthesis and assembly at the liquid/liquid interface, two kinds of precursors are generally dissolved in aqueous and oil phases, respectively. They diffuse to and adsorb at the interface and form a 2D structure finally through intermolecular reaction and self-assembly. The liquid/liquid interfacial method is the most widely used one among the interfacial methods, and various 2D nanostructures, most of them being nanosheets, have been prepared at the liquid/liquid interface, including graphyne, COFs, MOFs, coordination polymers, and so forth.

elements.content: Besides nanosheets, researchers are pursuing to prepare large-area 2D ultrathin films and have made great efforts for this purpose. Of course, Langmuir–Blodgett (LB) multilayers, layer-by-layer (LBL) multilayers, and lamellar films of block copolymers formed through microphase separation have always been important 2D ultrathin layered nanostructures. In addition to these films, it has been found that large-area 2D ultrathin films can be obtained at the air/liquid and liquid/liquid interfaces with the aid of confined reaction/assembly loci through the fine control of the conditions. Undoubtedly, the formation of ultrathin films is related to the molecular structure and intermolecular interactions, but the control of the reaction/assembly process is also very important. For example, a useful approach has been explored when using the liquid/liquid interfacial reaction/assembly method, that is, the liquid/liquid interface between a solution of one kind of precursor and a pure solvent was constructed first, and then another kind of precursor was added into the pure solvent gradually. Thus, the added precursor diffused to the interface gradually, the reaction/assembly of the two precursors was carried out gently, and large-area ultrathin films could be formed. Compared with LB and LBL multilayers, the 2D nanostructures formed at the liquid/liquid interface can be transferred easily onto various substrates, and sometimes self-supporting films can be obtained.

elements.content: We have synthesized two kinds of complexes of rare earth ions with bipyridine derivatives, Eu­(DN-bpy)2Cl3 and Eu­(DB-bpy)2Cl3, where DN-bpy and DB-bpy refer to 4,4′-dinonyl-2,2′-bipyridyl and 4,4′-di-tert-butyl-2,2′-bipyridyl, respectively. X-ray diffractometry (XRD) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) results indicated that a layered sheet-like structure was formed. It was expected that ultrathin nanosheets or large-area films would be formed at the liquid/liquid interface between an organic solution of the ligands and an aqueous solution of EuCl3 due to the confined reaction loci. It should be noted that the ligands of DN-bpy and DB-bpy are amphiphilic molecules, which should exhibit a different self-assembly behavior from that of the symmetric MOF-formed ligands when coordinating with metal ions at the liquid/liquid interface. In addition, it is anticipated to fabricate large-area ultrathin ordered coordination polymer films at the liquid/liquid interface using the modified method through nucleation and growth control. Therefore, two approaches were adopted, that is, the liquid/liquid interface was formed directly by covering the chloroform solution with the aqueous solution, or the liquid/liquid interface was formed first by covering the chloroform solution with pure water and then by adding an aqueous solution of EuCl3 dropwise into the water phase. It was noticed that nanosheets and large-area ultrathin layered films appeared at the interfaces in the two cases. The formation mechanism of the large-area thin films was investigated along with the effects of the molecular structure of the ligands, the interaction between the ligands, and the coordination types between the ligands and metal ions. It should be noted that such a large-area ultrathin layered coordination polymer film has not been fabricated before using the liquid/liquid interfacial assembling method or other methods such as the LB and LBL methods. This work provides a novel way to fabricate large-area ultrathin layered metal–organic films using common amphiphilic ligands.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Eu(DN-bpy)2Cl3 and Eu(DB-bpy)2Cl3 Powders

The powders of Eu(DN-bpy)2Cl3 and Eu(DB-bpy)2Cl3 were prepared in ethanol by mixing the ethanol solutions of EuCl3 and the ligands with a molar ratio of 1:2 of Eu3+ to ligands in stoichiometry. The powders were dispersed in water ultrasonically. The dispersions were dropped on the carbon-coated copper grids for TEM observation.

elements.content: The films were prepared through a reaction between the ligands and metal ions at the liquid/liquid interface. Clean and dry glass vials with an inner diameter of 3.5 cm were used as reaction containers. A certain amount of ligand such as DN-bpy was dissolved in chloroform with a concentration of 0.2 mg mL–1. This solution (5 mL) was poured into a glass vial, and then pure water (5 mL) was gently added to cover the organic solution, which was used as a buffer layer. Then, a certain volume of aqueous solution of an inorganic salt such as EuCl3 was dropwise added at a concentration of 5 × 10–2 mol·L–1 into the buffer layer using a microsyringe. For the system of DN-bpy and EuCl3, the volumes of the aqueous solution were 25, 123, and 246 μL, corresponding to the molar ratios of Eu3+ ions to DN-bpy of 0.5:1, 2.5:1, and 5:1, respectively. The reaction system was placed in a closed container. After 24 h, a thin film appeared at the liquid/liquid interface. The preparation process is presented schematically in Figure S1. The upper phase (aqueous solution) was removed using a pipette; then, the film appeared on the surface of the bottom phase. The thin film was deposited onto different substrates, including carbon-coated copper grids and silicon wafers using the LB technique.

The films were prepared through a reaction between the ligands and metal ions at the liquid/liquid interface. Clean and dry glass vials with an inner diameter of 3.5 cm were used as reaction containers. A certain amount of ligand such as DN-bpy was dissolved in chloroform with a concentration of 0.2 mg mL-1. This solution (5 mL) was poured into a glass vial, and then pure water (5 mL) was gently added to cover the organic solution, which was used as a buffer layer. Then, a certain volume of aqueous solution of an inorganic salt such as EuCl3 was dropwise added at a concentration of 5 × 10-2 mol⋅L-1 into the buffer layer using a microsyringe. For the system of DN-bpy and EuCl3, the volumes of the aqueous solution were 25, 123, and 246 μL, corresponding to the molar ratios of Eu3+ ions to DN-bpy of 0.5:1, 2.5:1, and 5:1, respectively. The reaction system was placed in a closed container. After 24 h, a thin film appeared at the liquid/liquid interface. The preparation process is presented schematically in Figure S1. The upper phase (aqueous solution) was removed using a pipette; then, the film appeared on the surface of the bottom phase. The thin film was deposited onto different substrates, including carbon-coated copper grids and silicon wafers using the LB technique.

elements.content: The morphology and structure of the films appeared at the liquid/liquid interface were investigated by TEM (JEOL-1011, acceleration voltage: 100 kV), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Model JSM-7600F), and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL-2010, acceleration voltage: 200 kV). The elemental analysis was carried out using an energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS) connected with a high-resolution transmission electron microscope and a field emission scanning electron microscope. The lamellar structure of the powders and films was further verified by using XRD (Rigaku D/Max 2200PC).

Characterization

Sheet-like structure and multilevel diffraction peaks corresponding to the (00l) crystal planes appeared, indicating that the powders have a layered structure. The d-spacings were calculated to be 1.57 and 1.20 nm for Eu­(DN-bpy)2Cl3 and Eu­(DB-bpy)2Cl3, respectively. elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Characterization of Ultrathin Layered Films

 Figure S2 shows the TEM images and XRD patterns of the powders. Sheet-like structure and multilevel diffraction peaks corresponding to the (00l) crystal planes appeared, indicating that the powders have a layered structure. The d-spacings were calculated to be 1.57 and 1.20 nm for Eu(DN-bpy)2Cl3 and Eu(DB-bpy)2Cl3, respectively. We inferred from these results that ultrathin layered nanosheets would be fabricated at the liquid/liquid interface with the aid of the confined reaction sites.

elements.content: Two approaches were designed and tried to prepare layered nanosheets. In approach I, the chloroform solutions of the ligands were covered directly by the aqueous solution of EuCl3 to form a liquid/liquid interface. Thin nanosheets appeared at the interface, as shown in Figure S3b,d. In approach II, the chloroform solution was covered by pure water first. At this time, irregular aggregates appeared at the interface without dropping the aqueous solution of EuCl3 into the upper phase (Figure S3a,c). Then, the aqueous solution was added into the water phase gradually. We observed clearly that large-area ultrathin films appeared at the interface. Compared with the nanosheets, it is obvious that the ultrathin films are more interesting and worthy of investigation.

elements.content: shows the TEM, HRTEM, and SEM images and the XRD pattern of the formed DN-bpy/Eu­(III) films. It can be seen that the films had gradually changed from ultrathin nanosheets to large-area ultrathin films by increasing the amount of EuCl3 aqueous solution, and the size and thickness of the films had increased significantly. A multilayer superimposed structure appeared, as can be seen in c. In fact, this structure resulted from the multiple folding of the ultrathin film. The liquid–liquid interface disappeared after removing the upper phase; therefore, the liquid/liquid interfacial tension and the interaction between the film and the upper phase were eliminated. Hence, the film folded due to the unbalanced forces. It can be inferred based on the folding times and the width of the film shown in c that the length can reach more than 200 μm if the film is unfolded, indicating that a large-area homogeneous ultrathin film forms at the interface. The SEM observation is consistent with the TEM observation (d). A large-area homogeneous flat thin film appeared, and the folded edges can be seen clearly. From the HRTEM image of the folded structure, one can see a clear layered structure with an interlayer spacing of about 3 nm (e). Several lamellar structures of inorganic and organic crystals and inorganic/organic hybrids were confirmed by HRTEM imaging. In some cases, the interplanar distance obtained from the TEM images was not in accordance with the actual situation sometimes due to the removal of residual ligands or solvents between the layers in organic/inorganic hybrids under a high vacuum, and it can still be used as a qualitative criterion for the layered structure. f shows the XRD pattern of the film. Two peaks corresponding to the (001) and (003) crystal planes of the layered structure appeared, and the d-spacing was calculated to be 1.32 nm. This value is much less than the interlayer spacing obtained from the HRTEM image, indicating the structural change of the films under a high vacuum. This may be attributed to the evaporation of some small molecules incorporated in the film, such as water molecules. The more likely reason should be the folding of the film, which may cause the structural changes, distortion, or superposition of the layered structure, leading to incorrect information. This value is slightly less than 1.57 nm, the d-spacing of the Eu­(DN-bpy)2Cl3 powder, indicating the difference between the two kinds of structures, possibly arising from the different orientations of the alkyl chains in these structures because of the different microenvironments. The EDS results further confirmed the existence of N, Eu, and Cl elements (Figure S4).

elements.content: The DB-bpy/Eu­(III) film was also fabricated at the liquid/liquid interface by the same procedure. The TEM (a–c) and SEM (d) images revealed that large-area homogeneous ultrathin films were generated. From the HRTEM image of the folding edge, we can see that the film has a layered structure, and an interlayer spacing of about 3 nm was measured (e). The d-spacing of the DB-bpy/Eu­(III) film was calculated to be 1.19 nm based on the XRD pattern (f), which is fully consistent with that of the powder, implying that the film and the powder have the same structure and composition. That is to say, two ligand molecules coordinate to one Eu3+ ion in the film. This further demonstrates that the tert-butyl group does not have a significant effect on the d-spacing because it is much shorter than the nonyl group in DN-bpy. The interlayer distance obtained from the HRTEM image is much larger than the d-spacing of the DB-bpy/Eu­(III) thin film, further reflecting the structural change under a high vacuum or distortion and superposition of the layered structures.

elements.content: It is clear that the formed films of DN-bpy/Eu­(III), DN-bpy/Cu­(II), and DB-bpy/Eu­(III) have a layered structure, and the interlayer spacings of DN-bpy/Eu­(III) and DB-bpy/Eu­(III) are 1.32 and 1.19 nm, respectively, based on the XRD results. The ligands, DN-bpy and DB-bpy, are amphiphilic molecules and can coordinate with metal ions. Therefore, the formation of the composite ultrathin films should be the result of several weaker interactions, including coordination of the bpy groups to metal ions, π–π interaction between the bpy rings, and the hydrophobic effect of the alkyl chains. If the bpy rings lie flat on the interface, as shown in Figure S5a, the interlayer spacing of the DN-bpy/Eu­(III) film can be tuned to be close to the measured value by changing the tilting angle of the nonyl chains or adopting interdigital configuration. However, the interlayer spacing of the DB-bpy/Eu­(III) film should be much less than the measured value. Hence, it is reasonable to suppose that the bpy rings stand upright at the interface. In this case, the interlayer spacing of the DB-bpy/Eu­(III) film was calculated to be 1.31 nm, slightly longer than the measured value of 1.19 nm, which would be attributed to the tilting of the bpy rings. The DN-bpy/Eu­(III) film should have a similar structure with the flat and intertwined nonyl chains. Based on the discussion, the film structures of DN-bpy/Eu­(III) and DB-bpy/Eu­(III) are proposed in a,b. The Cl– ions should coordinate to Eu3+ in the film due to the high coordination number of the Eu3+ ions. DN-bpy formed layered ultrathin films with Eu­(III) and Cu­(II) when using EuCl3 and Cu­(Ac)2, respectively, indicating that the counterions seem not to affect the film formation.

elements.content: It was seen from that DN-bpy molecules formed ultrathin films with Cu­(II) but formed irregular aggregates with Zn­(II). This should be attributed to the different coordination types between the ligands and the metal ions. Cu­(II) ions adopted dsp2 hybridization mode to form a plane square configuration, whereas Zn­(II) ions adopted sp3 hybridization mode to form a tetrahedral configuration. Thus, the two bpy groups coordinated to Cu2+ are coplanar, facilitating the π–π interaction between the adjacent bpy groups. However, the two bpy rings coordinated to Zn2+ are non-coplanar, weakening the π–π interaction between the adjacent bpy groups. Therefore, ultrathin layered films formed by the synergistic effects of the hydrophobic effect of alkyl chains, coordination interaction between the ligand and Cu2+, and π–π interaction between the ligand rings. Based on these results, we consider that the coordination and π–π interaction are important in the formation of ultrathin films.

elements.content: In order to explore the formation process of ultrathin layered films, the aggregates formed at the liquid/liquid interface at different time intervals were investigated by TEM. The results are shown in . After 30 min of adding EuCl3 aqueous solution into the water phase, large solid spheres with the diameter ranging from 200 to 400 nm and films with the size of several micrometers were generated at the liquid/liquid interface, as shown in a,b. No layered structure was seen from the HRTEM image (c), indicating that the film may be a monolayer. A layered structure appeared with the lapse of time, and a large-area layered film can be recognized after 2 h (d). Furthermore, the lamellar structure was clearly observed from the HRTEM image of the folded edge (e). Besides the layered films, nanosheets of tens of nanometers in size with some holes appeared, and the spheres disappeared (e). These results indicated that the sphere was an intermediate state that would dissociate with time. The thickness of the film increased with time, indicating that the layered structure grew layer by layer with time. The EDS spectra shown in Figure S6 indicated the existence of N and Eu elements in the aggregates.

Figure S7 exhibits the TEM micrographs of the aggregates of Bpy/Eu­(III), Phen/Eu­(III), and DM-bpy/Eu­(III) that appeared at the liquid/liquid interface. Nanosheets of hundreds of nanometers in size and regular elongated nanobelts with a width of about 50 nm and length of 500 nm appeared for the bpy/Eu­(III) (Figure S7a) and Phen/Eu­(III) (Figure S7 b) systems, respectively, and a thin film formed for the DM-bpy/Eu­(III) system (Figure S7c). bpy and Phen do not have obvious amphiphilicity, whereas DM-bpy with two methyl groups has weaker hydrophobicity. elements.clean_text:
Formation Mechanism of Ultrathin Layered Films

It was shown that nanosheets were obtained through approach I (Figure S3b,d). In this case, as soon as the planar liquid/liquid interface was formed, a large number of metal ions would quickly combine with the ligands through coordination interactions, resulting in the formation of small-sized nanosheets.

elements.content: In the case where large-area ultrathin layered films were obtained through approach II, the bipyridine ligands would be absorbed at the interface due to their amphiphilicity after the formation of the pure water/chloroform solution interface. With the slow addition of the aqueous solution into the water phase, Eu3+ ions would diffuse to the interface and combine with the ligands gradually in the interfacial phase and further assemble through coordination interactions and hydrophobic effects between the ligands. In a relatively short period of time, a lot of ligand molecules could aggregate into nanospheres due to the intermolecular interactions, and some ligand molecules could assemble with Eu3+ ions into a thin film. As the reaction time increased, more and more Eu3+ ions diffused to the interface and combined with the ligands, and the nanospheres dissociated gradually, leading to the growth of the original monolayer. Finally, a large-area layered ultrathin film was formed.

elements.content: It is clear that the formation of large-area layered ultrathin films is a result of synergistic effect of several factors. The first is the restriction of the interface. Another factor should be the modification of the addition process of the aqueous solution of metal ions into the water phase. We did not get ultrathin layered films using approach I, instead a large number of nanosheets were formed through consuming metal ions and ligands in a short time. Thus, the nanosheets could not grow continuously and attach to each other to form a large-area film, too. The other factor is the properties of the ligands and metal ions. For example, DN-bpy, DB-bpy, and DM-bpy can form large-area layered films with Eu3+ and Cu2+, whereas bpy and Phen just form nanosheets with Eu3+. When using Zn2+, no nanosheet and film form. This should be related to the intermolecular interactions and coordination types.

Effects of the Amount of Metal Ions

Our successful discovery of the preparation of ultrathin films reinforces that the films would grow again along the vertical direction to increase the number of layers. With this in mind, much more aqueous solution was added into the aqueous phase after the formation of the liquid/liquid interface between pure water and the chloroform solution of DN-bpy.

elements.content: Figure S8 shows the TEM images of the film formed at the interface when adding 2 mL of aqueous solution of EuCl3 into the upper phase at one time. It can be seen that a large number of ultrathin nanosheets accumulated into a flower structure rather than the expected uniform large-area film (Figure S8a,b). Then, we changed the sampling method: 1 mL of aqueous solution was added first, and then 1 mL of aqueous solution was added every 12 h. As shown in Figure S9a,b, two kinds of structures, that is, thin films and thick nanosheets, formed when adding 2 mL of the aqueous solution in total. When adding 5 mL of the aqueous solution in total, thicker nanosheets appeared, and the thin films disappeared (Figure S9c,d). This indicated that an ultrathin layered film could be formed at first when adding 1 mL of aqueous solution, and then the excessive Eu3+ ions competed with those in the film for the ligands when adding additional solution and further destroyed the film. At the same time, the interfacial phase became thicker and thicker, and the broken pieces of the film grew into thicker sheets. This indicated that the number of layers of the large-area film should have a limitation.

elements.content: In summary, large-area layered ultrathin films of amphiphilic ligands and metal ions were fabricated at the liquid/liquid interface, whose structure is different from that of the MOF films formed at the air/liquid and liquid/liquid interfaces. The formation of ultrathin films was attributed to the synergistic effects of the hydrophobic effects of alkyl chains, coordination bonds between the ligands and the metal ions, and π–π interactions between the ligands. Among these interactions, hydrophobic effects and coordination bonds should be the key factors for the formation of large-area coordination polymer ultrathin films based on the observations of DN-bpy, DB-bpy, DM-bpy, and bpy systems and on the results with and without adding aqueous solutions of metal ions into the water phase. The film formation is a result of continuous epitaxial growth of the film and the restriction of the interface. It was also found that the interfacial thickness exhibited great influence on the formation of nanostructures at the interface. This method is expected to be developed into a universal one to fabricate functional large-area ultrathin layered metal–organic films. In addition, these layered films should have potential applications in some areas due to their large specific surface area and a regular structure.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, large-area layered ultrathin films of amphiphilic ligands and metal ions were fabricated at the liquid/liquid interface, whose structure is different from that of the MOF films formed at the air/liquid and liquid/liquid interfaces. The formation of ultrathin films was attributed to the synergistic effects of the hydrophobic effects of alkyl chains, coordination bonds between the ligands and the metal ions, and π-π interactions between the ligands. Among these interactions, hydrophobic effects and coordination bonds should be the key factors for the formation of large-area coordination polymer ultrathin films based on the observations of DN-bpy, DB-bpy, DM-bpy, and bpy systems and on the results with and without adding aqueous solutions of metal ions into the water phase. The film formation is a result of continuous epitaxial growth of the film and the restriction of the interface. It was also found that the interfacial thickness exhibited great influence on the formation of nanostructures at the interface. This method is expected to be developed into a universal one to fabricate functional large-area ultrathin layered metal-organic films. In addition, these layered films should have potential applications in some areas due to their large specific surface area and a regular structure.

cln_elements.content: The films were prepared through a reaction between the ligands and metal ions at the liquid/liquid interface. Clean and dry glass vials with an inner diameter of 3.5 cm were used as reaction containers. A certain amount of ligand such as DN-bpy was dissolved in chloroform with a concentration of 0.2 mg mL–1. This solution (5 mL) was poured into a glass vial, and then pure water (5 mL) was gently added to cover the organic solution, which was used as a buffer layer. Then, a certain volume of aqueous solution of an inorganic salt such as EuCl3 was dropwise added at a concentration of 5 × 10–2 mol·L–1 into the buffer layer using a microsyringe. For the system of DN-bpy and EuCl3, the volumes of the aqueous solution were 25, 123, and 246 μL, corresponding to the molar ratios of Eu3+ ions to DN-bpy of 0.5:1, 2.5:1, and 5:1, respectively. The reaction system was placed in a closed container. After 24 h, a thin film appeared at the liquid/liquid interface. The preparation process is presented schematically in Figure S1. The upper phase (aqueous solution) was removed using a pipette; then, the film appeared on the surface of the bottom phase. The thin film was deposited onto different substrates, including carbon-coated copper grids and silicon wafers using the LB technique.

Preparation of Ultrathin Layered Films at the Liquid/Liquid Interface

The films were prepared through a reaction between the ligands and metal ions at the liquid/liquid interface. Clean and dry glass vials with an inner diameter of 3.5 cm were used as reaction containers. A certain amount of ligand such as DN-bpy was dissolved in chloroform with a concentration of 0.2 mg mL-1. This solution (5 mL) was poured into a glass vial, and then pure water (5 mL) was gently added to cover the organic solution, which was used as a buffer layer. Then, a certain volume of aqueous solution of an inorganic salt such as EuCl3 was dropwise added at a concentration of 5 × 10-2 mol⋅L-1 into the buffer layer using a microsyringe. For the system of DN-bpy and EuCl3, the volumes of the aqueous solution were 25, 123, and 246 μL, corresponding to the molar ratios of Eu3+ ions to DN-bpy of 0.5:1, 2.5:1, and 5:1, respectively. The reaction system was placed in a closed container. After 24 h, a thin film appeared at the liquid/liquid interface. The preparation process is presented schematically in Figure S1. The upper phase (aqueous solution) was removed using a pipette; then, the film appeared on the surface of the bottom phase. The thin film was deposited onto different substrates, including carbon-coated copper grids and silicon wafers using the LB technique.

shows the TEM, HRTEM, and SEM images and the XRD pattern of the formed DN-bpy/Eu­(III) films. It can be seen that the films had gradually changed from ultrathin nanosheets to large-area ultrathin films by increasing the amount of EuCl3 aqueous solution, and the size and thickness of the films had increased significantly. A multilayer superimposed structure appeared, as can be seen in c. In fact, this structure resulted from the multiple folding of the ultrathin film. The liquid–liquid interface disappeared after removing the upper phase; therefore, the liquid/liquid interfacial tension and the interaction between the film and the upper phase were eliminated. Hence, the film folded due to the unbalanced forces. It can be inferred based on the folding times and the width of the film shown in c that the length can reach more than 200 μm if the film is unfolded, indicating that a large-area homogeneous ultrathin film forms at the interface. The SEM observation is consistent with the TEM observation (d). A large-area homogeneous flat thin film appeared, and the folded edges can be seen clearly. From the HRTEM image of the folded structure, one can see a clear layered structure with an interlayer spacing of about 3 nm (e). Several lamellar structures of inorganic and organic crystals and inorganic/organic hybrids were confirmed by HRTEM imaging. In some cases, the interplanar distance obtained from the TEM images was not in accordance with the actual situation sometimes due to the removal of residual ligands or solvents between the layers in organic/inorganic hybrids under a high vacuum, and it can still be used as a qualitative criterion for the layered structure. f shows the XRD pattern of the film. Two peaks corresponding to the (001) and (003) crystal planes of the layered structure appeared, and the d-spacing was calculated to be 1.32 nm. This value is much less than the interlayer spacing obtained from the HRTEM image, indicating the structural change of the films under a high vacuum. This may be attributed to the evaporation of some small molecules incorporated in the film, such as water molecules. The more likely reason should be the folding of the film, which may cause the structural changes, distortion, or superposition of the layered structure, leading to incorrect information. This value is slightly less than 1.57 nm, the d-spacing of the Eu­(DN-bpy)2Cl3 powder, indicating the difference between the two kinds of structures, possibly arising from the different orientations of the alkyl chains in these structures because of the different microenvironments. The EDS results further confirmed the existence of N, Eu, and Cl elements (Figure S4).

It is clear that the formed films of DN-bpy/Eu­(III), DN-bpy/Cu­(II), and DB-bpy/Eu­(III) have a layered structure, and the interlayer spacings of DN-bpy/Eu­(III) and DB-bpy/Eu­(III) are 1.32 and 1.19 nm, respectively, based on the XRD results. The ligands, DN-bpy and DB-bpy, are amphiphilic molecules and can coordinate with metal ions. Therefore, the formation of the composite ultrathin films should be the result of several weaker interactions, including coordination of the bpy groups to metal ions, π–π interaction between the bpy rings, and the hydrophobic effect of the alkyl chains. If the bpy rings lie flat on the interface, as shown in Figure S5a, the interlayer spacing of the DN-bpy/Eu­(III) film can be tuned to be close to the measured value by changing the tilting angle of the nonyl chains or adopting interdigital configuration. However, the interlayer spacing of the DB-bpy/Eu­(III) film should be much less than the measured value. Hence, it is reasonable to suppose that the bpy rings stand upright at the interface. In this case, the interlayer spacing of the DB-bpy/Eu­(III) film was calculated to be 1.31 nm, slightly longer than the measured value of 1.19 nm, which would be attributed to the tilting of the bpy rings. The DN-bpy/Eu­(III) film should have a similar structure with the flat and intertwined nonyl chains. Based on the discussion, the film structures of DN-bpy/Eu­(III) and DB-bpy/Eu­(III) are proposed in a,b. The Cl– ions should coordinate to Eu3+ in the film due to the high coordination number of the Eu3+ ions. DN-bpy formed layered ultrathin films with Eu­(III) and Cu­(II) when using EuCl3 and Cu­(Ac)2, respectively, indicating that the counterions seem not to affect the film formation.

The more likely reason should be the folding of the film, which may cause the structural changes, distortion, or superposition of the layered structure, leading to incorrect information. This value is slightly less than 1.57 nm, the d-spacing of the Eu(DN-bpy)2Cl3 powder, indicating the difference between the two kinds of structures, possibly arising from the different orientations of the alkyl chains in these structures because of the different microenvironments. The EDS results further confirmed the existence of N, Eu, and Cl elements (Figure S4).

Film Structures

It is clear that the formed films of DN-bpy/Eu(III), DN-bpy/Cu(II), and DB-bpy/Eu(III) have a layered structure, and the interlayer spacings of DN-bpy/Eu(III) and DB-bpy/Eu(III) are 1.32 and 1.19 nm, respectively, based on the XRD results. The ligands, DN-bpy and DB-bpy, are amphiphilic molecules and can coordinate with metal ions. Therefore, the formation of the composite ultrathin films should be the result of several weaker interactions, including coordination of the bpy groups to metal ions, π-π interaction between the bpy rings, and the hydrophobic effect of the alkyl chains. If the bpy rings lie flat on the interface, as shown in Figure S5a, the interlayer spacing of the DN-bpy/Eu(III) film can be tuned to be close to the measured value by changing the tilting angle of the nonyl chains or adopting interdigital configuration. However, the interlayer spacing of the DB-bpy/Eu(III) film should be much less than the measured value. Hence, it is reasonable to suppose that the bpy rings stand upright at the interface. In this case, the interlayer spacing of the DB-bpy/Eu(III) film was calculated to be 1.31 nm, slightly longer than the measured value of 1.19 nm, which would be attributed to the tilting of the bpy rings. The DN-bpy/Eu(III) film should have a similar structure with the flat and intertwined nonyl chains. Based on the discussion, the film structures of DN-bpy/Eu(III) and DB-bpy/Eu(III) are proposed in a,b. The Cl- ions should coordinate to Eu3+ in the film due to the high coordination number of the Eu3+ ions. DN-bpy formed layered ultrathin films with Eu(III) and Cu(II) when using EuCl3 and Cu(Ac)2, respectively, indicating that the counterions seem not to affect the film formation.

Investigation of Bpy/Eu(III), Phen/Eu(III), and DM-bpy/Eu(III) Systems

Other ligands with different molecular structures were also used to fabricate nanostructures via the same approach. Figure S7 exhibits the TEM micrographs of the aggregates of Bpy/Eu(III), Phen/Eu(III), and DM-bpy/Eu(III) that appeared at the liquid/liquid interface. Nanosheets of hundreds of nanometers in size and regular elongated nanobelts with a width of about 50 nm and length of 500 nm appeared for the bpy/Eu(III) (Figure S7a) and Phen/Eu(III) (Figure S7 b) systems, respectively, and a thin film formed for the DM-bpy/Eu(III) system (Figure S7c). bpy and Phen do not have obvious amphiphilicity, whereas DM-bpy with two methyl groups has weaker hydrophobicity. Hence, these results proved the importance of hydrophobic interactions for the formation of large-area ultrathin films.
